metadata.title: A study of the tribological behaviour of TiO2 nano-additive water-based lubricants

sections.text:
A ball-on-disk tribometer was employed to evaluate the lubrication performance and mechanisms of innovative TiO2 nano-additive water-based lubricants. Two experimental methods were applied to determine the optimal mass fraction of TiO2. In the method I, lubricants were added onto the worn disk tracks at a predetermined time interval. In the method II, the disks were immersed in the lubricants continuously during the whole process of tribological tests. The results both indicate that the water-based lubricants can significantly reduce the coefficient of friction (COF). The 0.8 wt.% TiO2 lubricant
demonstrates excellent tribological properties including the lowest COF and the strongest wear resistance under all lubrication conditions. The lubrication mechanisms are attributed to the rolling and mending effects of the TiO2 nanoparticles.
Keywords: TiO2 nano-additive; Water-based lubricant; Ball-on-disk; Coefficient of friction

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Friction, wear and lubrication between materials in contact are of fundamental importance in engineering applications [1]. Reduction in friction and wear is one of the most important objectives of tribological research [2]. Due to the special physical and chemical properties of nanomaterials, many studies have been conducted in recent years using nanoparticles as additives in lubricating oil to improve the tribological properties of the lubricants [3-22]. Li et al. [8, 9] prepared well dispersed oil-based lubricants with nano-SiO2 as an additive in order to increase the anti-wear ability and reduce the COF under fourball and ring-on-block tests. A film formed by nano-SiO2 protected the metal-on-metal surfaces and filled in the wear scars. Some researchers [10, 12, 13, 16, 19] added Cu nanoparticles into the base oil to improve anti-wear, load-carrying and friction-reduction performance. The formation of Cu-containing boundary film prevents friction pairs from rubbing each other. Some researchers have also investigated the tribological properties of fullerene nano-additive mineral oil and found that the presence of such nanoparticles between the friction surfaces improved the lubricating performance by increasing the viscosity of the lubricating oil and preventing direct metal surface contact [5-7, 15, 17]. Composite nanoparticles have also been used as additives in lubricating oil in order to obtain improvement in antiwear, extreme pressure and friction-reducing properties because the individual component cannot perform effectively due to the restrained physicochemical properties [20-23].
Although nano-additive oil-based lubricants exhibit excellent lubrication performance for tribological applications, this inevitably leads to environmental pollution and there is also a problem with recycling them. Another problem is that the nozzles which supply the flow of the fluid are prone to being blocked and regular maintenance is required frequently. This all means that the development of an environmentfriendly water-based lubricant with superior lubrication performance becomes a trend in the field of lubrication.
Nowadays, few researchers have applied nanoparticles as additives in water-based lubricants and the results have been rarely reported. TiO2 is widely used as a nano-additive in oil-based lubricants [3, 4, 11], and lately it is being used more and more in water-based lubricants [24-26]. However, the role of nanoadditive dispersed in water and the corresponding lubrication mechanisms have not been clearly researched until now.
In the present work, the water-based lubricants with varying TiO2 nanoparticle additions were prepared, and the lubrication performance was evaluated using a ball-on-disk tribometer. The objective of this study is to understand the lubrication mechanisms of as-prepared lubricants through experimental analysis and lubrication modelling.
2. Experimental 2.1 Materials
A low-carbon microalloyed steel was adopted as disk material in this study. Its chemical compositions are listed in Table 1.
The surface morphologies and 3D profiles of both the applied ball and the disk are shown in Figs. 1(a)-(d). It can be seen that the surfaces of ball and disk are quite uniform and smooth. E52100 Cr steel balls with a diameter of 9.5 mm and an identical Ra of 0.02 µm were used for the ball-on-disk tests. The Vickers hardness of the ball material is 780 HV. All the disks for ball-on-disk tests were machined to 40 mm in diameter and 8 mm in thickness, and the surfaces were ground to be uniform with a roughness (Ra) of around 0.04 µm. The Vickers hardness of the disk material is 90 HV. These were to eliminate the influence of the original surface condition on the experimental results.
2.2 Preparation
The TiO2 nano-additive water-based lubricants were prepared following the flow chart shown in Fig. 2. First, TiO2 nanoparticles (P25 sourced from Sigma- Aldrich TM with a diameter approx.20 nm) were mixed into the deionised water by mechanical stirring. Then, polyethyleneimine (PEI) was gradually added into the solution followed by a high speed centrifuge at 20,000 rpm for 30 minutes to prepare a dispersive solution. PEI is a cationic polymer, which acts as a surfactant of TiO2 in order to improve the dispersing property of the nanoparticles. The PEI volume was determined as a balance to that of TiO2 nanoparticles. Afterwards, glycerol was added drop by drop. Glycerol is a colourless, odourless, and viscous liquid, which is primarily used to improve the viscosity of solutions. The suspension was then processed by ultrasonication with stirring for 10 minutes to break down any remaining agglomeration. The prepared
TiO2 nano-additive water-based lubricant showed good colloid stability, and no sedimentation could be observed during the 7 days of aging.
The chemical compositions of as-prepared lubricants are outlined in Table 2. The different lubrication conditions (shown in the Table 2 as numbered 1 – 9) were applied for tribological tests. The dry and water lubrication conditions were used as benchmarks in comparison to the lubrication effects of as-prepared water-based nano-additive lubricants. The water-based lubricants were composed of different mass fractions of TiO2 nanoparticles (from 0.2 to 8.0 wt.%), and corresponding mass fractions of PEI. The concentration of glycerol was fixed at 10.0 vol. % for each type of lubricant.
2.3 Tribological tests
An Rtec MFT-5000 Multi-functional Tribometer was employed to measure the COF values by ball-ondisk tribological tests. The basic configuration of the ball-on-disk tribometer is schematically shown in Fig. 3. The ball holder with Cr steel ball and the disk were cleaned with ethanol and then assembled prior to the tests. The disk was fastened to the disk holder by a screw and a small pin was inserted to ensure that the disk could be smoothly rotated together with the holder. The arm adjusted by a bubble level should be accurately horizontal in order to reduce experimental error. The normal force applied to the ball holder was measured by an Fz load cell installed above a spring. The friction force was induced by the combination of the rotating motion and the normal load, and it was measured by an Fx load cell attached to the right point of the arm. The disk holder and disk, which were controlled by a servo motor for rotating, were located in a liquid container. Two types of lubrication methods (defined as M-I and M-II) were used in this study, and the detailed experimental conditions were summarised in Tables 3 and 4, respectively.
Table 3 specifies the experimental conditions used in the M-I. The tests were conducted at room temperature, and each test was repeated for three times. Prior to the tests, the ball was located on the disk at a position of 14 mm in radius away from the central hole of the disk. Then the disk was applied with a normal force of 50 N and started to rotate with a linear speed of 20 mm/s, which was restricted to reduce the hydrodynamic effect of fluid. By calculation, the rotating speed of 13.65 rpm was obtained and was input into the computer software. The tribological tests were implemented under dry condition during the first five-minute rotation followed by continuous drops of lubricants onto the wear track during the remaining five minutes. This means that the M-I can be defined as “dry condition plus lubricants addition”.
Table 4 lists the experimental conditions used in the M-II. The tests were conducted at room temperature, and each test was repeated for three times. Prior to the tests, the disks were immersed into the fluid bath with a normal force of 50 N applied on the ball. The rotating linear speed was kept constant at 20 mm/s in order to reduce the hydrodynamic effect [27]. Tests under the same lubrication conditions were carried out with three tracks at radii of 14, 15, and 16mm, respectively, in order to obtain a mean COF value. Each track was generated following the same linear speed of 20 mm/s with corresponding rotating speeds of 13.65, 12.74, and 11.94 rpm, and each test lasted for 10 minutes. The M-II can be defined as “continuous lubrication condition”.
2.4 Characterisation methods
Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was implemented on a Philips PW1730 conventional diffraction meter with Cu-Kα radiation. Micrographs and size distribution of the TiO2 nanoparticles inside the water-based lubricants were obtained using a JEOL JEM-ARM200F Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) coupled with an energy-dispersive spectrometer (EDS).
The suspension stability of as-prepared TiO2 nano-additive water-based lubricants was characterised by a UV-1800 ultraviolet visible (UV-vis) spectrophotometer, which measured UV intensity of the suspension by evaluating the rate of nanoparticle sedimentation. The relative concentration was calculated by the ratio between the initial intensity of nanoparticle concentration and the following intensity on different days.
The wear tracks of balls and disks after tribological tests were cleaned in an ultrasonic acetone bath and observed under a KEYENCE VK-X100K 3D Laser Scanning Microscope, from which the 3D profile of the wear areas of both ball and disk were obtained. The wear scars of the balls were then observed using a JEOL model JSM-6490 and JSM-7001F Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) equipped with an EDS to evaluate the lubrication mechanisms.
3. Results and discussion 3.1 Materials Characterisation
The XRD patterns of the applied TiO2 nanoparticles are shown in Fig. 4, from which the phases of particles can be determined as typical P25 TiO2 containing 75% of anatase and 25% of rutile by referring to the XRD standard atlas.
Fig. 5 shows the TEM images and size distributions of TiO2 nanoparticles dried from varying concentrations from 0.4 wt.% to 4.0 wt.%. It can be clearly seen from Figs. 5(a), (c), (e), and (g) that the
majority of the nanoparticles are round in shape, and the nanoparticles are uniform and well dispersed with no apparent agglomeration even at high level of concentration such as 4.0 wt.%. The statistical analysis of size distributions indicates that the particle size has an average diameter of around 20 nm. With the increase of concentration up to 4.0 wt.%, only few nanoparticles agglomerate to a size above 40 nm, as shown in Figs. 5(b), (d), (f), and (h).
3.2 Suspension stability
Fig. 6 shows the stability of the as-prepared TiO2 nano-additive water-based lubricants. A value of 1.0 at the relative concentration means perfect stability of the suspension without particle sedimentation. For the lubricants with TiO2 concentrations of 0.2-2.0 wt.%, the relative absorption remains almost constant within four days, and it begins to decrease by around 17% on the fifth day. When the TiO2 concentration increases to 2.0-4.0 wt.%, however, the relative absorption drops by only 15% within four days and it continues to drop until it reaches around 80%. The results indicate that all the as-prepared lubricants exhibit superb stability within 120 h even for the ones with high concentrations.
3.3 Tribological tests 3.3.1 Level of uncertainty
The level of uncertainty is evaluated by the repeated tests, as shown in Fig. 7. The lubricant with 0.8 wt.% TiO2 is alternative as an example to add onto the disk after five-minute dry friction following M-I. It can be seen in Fig. 7(a) that the in-situ COF curves fluctuate severely because of a high sampling frequency but show quite consistent trends in the whole process. In order to specify the detailed difference between the two curves, the processed ones are obtained in Fig. 7(b) by smoothing. In the first half duration, the main trends can be well overlapped except for minor difference due to abrasive ploughing under dry condition. In the second half duration, however, the COF values on the two disks are almost identical with the addition of 0.8 wt.% TiO2 lubricant. The whole process, therefore, indicates that the level of uncertainty on the experimental results can be well controlled owning to the excellent repeatability.
3.3.2 Dry condition plus lubricants addition
Fig. 8 shows the COF values before and after the addition of lubricants onto the disks. During the first half of the testing process, the dry condition leads to remarkable fluctuation in the running-in period due to the severe friction between the ball and the disk with a transition from sliding to ploughing. Then the COF decreases until a stable stage is reached where the ball rotates gently on a uniform worn track. The drop of the COF can be ascribed to the formation of wear debris, which can behave as third body lubrication [28, 29]. Besides, oxides are inclined to be produced during the rubbing of the two metallic
surfaces with presence of frictional heat [30]. In particular, the development of compacted oxides and tribo-oxide layer contributes to lower and stabilise the COF [30, 31]. With the addition of lubricants onto the worn disk track, the COF values reduce significantly followed by smooth curves to the end of the tests. It is clear that water-based lubricants with the addition of different amounts of TiO2 have much lower COF values than that of water. However, the reduced COF curves of water-based lubricants cannot be distinguished obviously in this figure as they are quite close to each other. The detailed difference of these COF values is shown in Fig. 9(a).
Figs. 9(a) and (b) show the COF values and the wear areas of balls, respectively, after the addition of lubricants. Compared to the COF under dry condition, water and water-based lubricants all exhibit prominent lubrication effects, especially for the water-based lubricants with nano-additives, whose COF values decrease continuously with an increase in the mass fraction of TiO2 and reach the lowest value when 0.8 wt.% TiO2 is added, as shown in Fig. 9(a). A rising COF value is observed when the TiO2 fraction is further increased to 2.0 wt.%, but it remains almost constant even when the TiO2 fraction increases to 8.0 wt.%.
The ball wear under different lubrication conditions is shown in Fig. 9(b). It can be seen that the addition of 0.8 wt.% TiO2 leads to the lowest ball wear, which is consistent with the COF values indicated in Fig. 9(a). Fig. 10 shows the 3D profile images of the ball wear areas. It can be seen that water produces a wear area of 2239 µm 2 along Z axis (depth). On the other hand, the water-based lubricants with additions of 0.4, 0.8 and 4.0 wt.% TiO2 result in much smaller wear areas than that caused by water. Among the waterbased lubricants, the worn surface becomes smoother when the mass fraction of TiO2 reaches 0.8 wt.%, indicating that 0.8 wt.% TiO2-containing lubricant has better wear resistance than any other lubrication conditions. Based on the 3D profile images, abrasive ploughing is supposed to be the main wear manner for all the friction processes. This will be discussed later in this paper along with the further explanation of the lubrication mechanisms.
3.3.3 Continuous lubrication condition
Fig. 11 shows the tribological properties under continuous lubrication conditions with water and waterbased lubricants. It is similar to the results shown in Fig. 9 that 0.8 wt.% TiO2 exhibits the best lubrication effects of all. In addition, the wear areas of both the disk and the ball along the Z axis also support that 0.8 wt.% could be the optimal mass faction for TiO2 nano-additive water based lubricants at room temperature. The 3D profile images of the disk wear areas are shown in Fig. 12. It can be seen that the water lubrication generates abrasive friction and the wear area along Z axis (depth) is 1371 µm 2 . While with addition of TiO2 nanoparticles at lower fractions of 0.2 and 0.8 wt.%, the wear areas decrease to
around 1000 µm 2 . However, the wear area increases to 1977 µm 2 when lubricated by 4.0 wt.% TiO2, which is the highest among all the lubrication conditions being used. Detailed image analyses in Figs. 12(b) and (c) show that furrows exist only inside the wear tracks lubricated by 0.2 and 0.8 wt.% TiO2. The possible reason is that the lower fraction of TiO2 nano-additive makes it much easier for particles to enter the rubbing zone and has a better lubrication effect than lubricants with higher fraction such as 4.0 wt.% [32]. The sudden change in the 3D profiles with ridges and valleys can be ascribed to the rubbing between the particles and disk, which indicates that the nanoparticles are able to act as ball bearings to decrease COF and wear [17, 18, 28, 33]. In this case, both the ball and disk wear caused by 0.2-0.8 wt.% TiO2 lubrications tend to be at a lower level compared with those conducted by 2.0-8.0 wt.% TiO2 lubrications. The TiO2 nanoparticles from lubricants with higher concentrations, differently, incline to deposit around the rubbing zone and aggravate wear by abrading the edge of the wear track. It is shown in Fig. 12(d) that the track is much wider than those in Figs. 12(a)-(c).
3.4 Lubrication mechanisms
A number of lubrication mechanisms have been proposed to explain the improvement of the lubrication effects through using nanoparticles as additives in lubricating oil, including the rolling effect [3, 17, 21, 28, 32-34], the mending effect [16], the polishing effect [3, 32, 35] and the protective film [4, 8, 10, 11, 13, 14, 19, 36-40], as schematically shown in Fig. 13 in terms of ball-on-disk friction. The rolling effect and protective film are mainly used to separate the friction pairs rubbing against each other as a result of COF reduction, while the mending and polishing effects act on the enhancement of surface quality. In this study, the lubrication mechanisms of the TiO2 nano-additive water-based lubricants will be examined based on the four lubrication mechanisms.
Fig. 14 shows the SEM images and EDS mappings of the disk samples lubricated by the water-based suspension with 0.2-4.0 wt.% TiO2. It can be seen that a large number of TiO2 nanoparticles have significantly filled in the defects of the disk surfaces, no matter what concentrations are the lubricants. In comparison to the SEM images shown in Figs. 14(a)-(d), the bright zones in O and Ti mappings present direct evidence to support this phenomenon, which can be defined as the “mending effect”. With the increase of mass fractions of TiO2, the mending effect becomes more distinct.
Figs. 15(a)-(d) show the SEM images of the disk samples lubricated by 0.2, 0.8, 2.0, and 4.0 wt.% TiO2, respectively. Figs. 15(e) and (f) give the EDS spectra to show the element titanium. It can be seen that TiO2 nanoparticles are distributed dispersedly on the worn disk track surfaces, indicating that the spherical TiO2 nanoparticles in the lubricant can roll between the rubbing surfaces in the friction process. This “rolling effect” of TiO2 nanoparticles in water-based lubricants contributes to a significant reduction
of COF in comparison to that caused by water. When the mass fraction of the TiO2 is below 0.8 wt.% (such as 0.2 wt.%), as shown in Fig. 15(a), particle-depleted zones appear in the worn disk track, which means few nanoparticles act between the rubbing surfaces, and thus the reduction of COF and wear area are insignificant. When the mass fraction of TiO2 nanoparticles increases to above 0.8 wt.%, as shown in Figs. 15(c)-(d), some nanoparticles are agglomerated, and consequently the secondary particle size becomes larger (around 50 nm for 2.0 wt.% TiO2 and 100 nm for 4.0 wt.% TiO2). This would deteriorate the friction and wear, and therefore lead to the increase in COF and wear area [21]. Differently, as shown in Fig. 15(b), the disk surface lubricated by 0.8 wt.% TiO2 has numerous nanoparticles distributed evenly with a small diameter, which results in even lower COF and a smaller wear area as compared to other lubricants with different TiO2-additions. This indicates that the 0.8 wt.% is considered to be the optimal mass fraction of TiO2 in the as-prepared water-based lubricants.
Fig. 16 demonstrates the lubrication mechanisms with TiO2 mass fractions of 0.2, 0.8, and 4.0 wt.%. Under the lubricant of TiO2 with a fraction of 0.2 wt.% (see Fig. 16(a)), few nanoparticles can enter the rubbing surfaces, and as a result the lubrication effect appears to be insignificant. When the TiO2 fraction increases to 4.0 wt.%, as shown in Fig. 16(c), a large amount of nanoparticles accumulate around the rubbing zone to form a barrier which affects the continuous supply of nanoparticles to the zone for lubrication [32]. Moreover, the large particles which can still roll between the ball and disk are supposed to deteriorate the wear zone during rubbing process [21]. In addition, the severe wear is supposed to be produced by the large particles abrading the edge of the wear track. On the other hand, the 0.8 wt.% TiO2containing lubricant is able to feed abundant nanoparticles continuously to the rubbing zone with little agglomeration, as shown in Fig. 16(b). Therefore, 0.8 wt.% is thought to be the optimal mass fraction of TiO2 as the best tribological properties including the lowest COF and the strongest wear resistance have been obtained.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The lubrication properties of TiO2 nano-additive water-based lubricants were evaluated by the ball-ondisk tests at room temperature using two different testing methods. The conclusions drawn from this study are shown below.
(1) The lubricants with superb dispersion and stability characterised by TEM and UV-vis have been
prepared.
(2) The addition of TiO2 nanoparticles into water significantly reduces the COF and improves the wear
resistance. The COF and ball wear can be decreased by 49.5% and 97.8%, respectively, compared to those obtained from the dry condition. (3) The lubricants with low fractions of TiO2 below 0.8 wt.% enable few nanoparticles to enter the
rubbing zone to reduce the COF; while the lubricants with high fractions of TiO2 above 0.8 wt. % result in agglomeration of nanoparticles and thus increase the COF. (4) 0.8 wt.% TiO2 water-based lubricant leads to the lowest COF and the best anti-wear ability under all
the lubrication conditions at room temperature.
(5) The rolling and mending effects are considered as the lubrication mechanisms of TiO2 nano-additive
water-based lubricants.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: The authors wish to acknowledge the financial support from Baosteel-Australia Joint Research and Development Centre (BAJC) under project of BA-13012 and the Australian Research Council (ARC) under Linkage Project Program (LP150100591). The first author is greatly thankful for the scholarship support (IPTA & UPA) from University of Wollongong and scholarship support from China Scholarship Council (CSC). The authors are also grateful to Mr. Liang Luo on schematic drawing of the tribometer, Mr. Stuart Rodd and other technicians in the workshop of SMART Infrastructure Facility for their great support on samples machining. The authors would like to extend special thanks to Dr. Madeleine Strong Cincotta in the final language editing of this paper.

referenceMentions.context: Friction, wear and lubrication between materials in contact are of fundamental importance in engineering applications [1].
Reduction in friction and wear is one of the most important objectives of tribological research [2].

Due to the special physical and chemical properties of nanomaterials, many studies have been conducted in recent years using nanoparticles as additives in lubricating oil to improve the tribological properties of the lubricants [3-22].

metadata.abstractText: A ball-on-disk tribometer was employed to evaluate the lubrication performance and mechanisms of innovative TiO2 nano-additive water-based lubricants. Two experimental methods were applied to determine the optimal mass fraction of TiO2. In the method I, lubricants were added onto the worn disk tracks at a predetermined time interval. In the method II, the disks were immersed in the lubricants continuously during the whole process of tribological tests. The results both indicate that the water-based lubricants can significantly reduce the coefficient of friction (COF). The 0.8 wt.% TiO2 lubricant
metadata.creator: Elsevier
